Line 192: Line 192:
Not all Major League baseball teams have similar revenue streams, which contributes to a disparity of "haves" and "have-nots" amongst franchises. Major League Baseball franchises average spending 48.9% of every revenue dollar on player payroll while the Rockies spent 28.4% of team revenues on player payroll.<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Baseball Team Valuations |url=http://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/33/Rank_1.html |accessdate=2007-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |title=2006 Salaries |url=http://sportsline.com/mlb/salaries |accessdate=2007-09-26}}</ref> Only one team in all of MLB spends a lower proportion of team revenues on player payroll than the Rockies.{{Who|date=December 2007}}
Not all Major League baseball teams have similar revenue streams, which contributes to a disparity of "haves" and "have-nots" amongst franchises. Major League Baseball franchises average spending 48.9% of every revenue dollar on player payroll while the Rockies spent 28.4% of team revenues on player payroll.<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Baseball Team Valuations |url=http://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/33/Rank_1.html |accessdate=2007-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |title=2006 Salaries |url=http://sportsline.com/mlb/salaries |accessdate=2007-09-26}}</ref> Only one team in all of MLB spends a lower proportion of team revenues on player payroll than the Rockies.{{Who|date=December 2007}}
